title: How to Prevent Blue Hair from Turning Green

steps.title: Purple shampoo helps cancel out the yellow tones in your hair.
steps.content: Purple shampoo helps cancel out the yellow tones in your hair. These yellow tones, when mixed with the blue hair dye, can lead to a greenish tint in your locks. [2] X Research source Wash your hair with your traditional shampoo; after rinsing it out, lather your hair with purple shampoo. [3] X Research source Let this product sit for a few minutes before rinsing it out. As a good rule of thumb, use this shampoo 1-2 times a week to help tone your hair. [4] X Research source If your hair is lighter, platinum blonde shade, your hair might not look as green over time.

steps.title: Fill a clean, empty jar ¼ of the way full with a deep conditioner.
steps.content: Fill a clean, empty jar ¼ of the way full with a deep conditioner. Stir 1 spoonful of blue, vegetable-based, semi-permanent hair dye into your conditioner. Massage the colored conditioner into your hair, combing it through your strands to spread out the mixture. Then, clip away your hair so it’s out of your face, and let the conditioners sit for 5 minutes. Rinse out the mixture completely afterward. [5] X Research source You can use this mixture when you shower to recharge your beautiful blue hair.

steps.title: Don’t crank up the heat when you step in the shower.
steps.content: Don’t crank up the heat when you step in the shower. From a scientific standpoint, hot water causes fading by lifting up your hair’s outer cuticle layer. To prevent this from happening, set your tap to a lukewarm or cold setting, which will preserve your hair color for longer. [6] X Research source The higher the water temperature, the faster your color will fade.

steps.title: Don’t hit the showers every day.
steps.content: Don’t hit the showers every day. Unfortunately, dyed hair fades a little bit each time you lather up with shampoo. Instead, space out your showers so you can keep your hair clean and fresh without compromising the color. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Sulfates tend to strip away your hair’s moisture, natural oils, and dyed color.
steps.content: Sulfates tend to strip away your hair’s moisture, natural oils, and dyed color. To prevent this, check the shampoo and conditioner labels while you’re at the store. Pick up products labeled specifically as “sulfate-free,” and toss out any old products that list sodium laureth sulfate or sodium laureth ether sulfate as an ingredient. [8] X Research source You can also look for products that are designed and labeled for color-treated hair. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Shop for dry shampoos with “color-safe” on the label.
steps.content: Shop for dry shampoos with “color-safe” on the label. On the days you skip the shower, spray dry shampoo in your hair to keep it fresh. [10] X Research source You can also look for a color-tinted dry shampoo that matches the blue shade of your hair.

steps.title: Soak up any leftover water with a towel after your shower.
steps.content: Soak up any leftover water with a towel after your shower. Then, let your hair air-dry the rest of the way. Don’t use a blow dryer too often—this can damage your locks. [11] X Research source Don’t overdo it when you towel-dry your hair. Unfortunately, scrubbing your hair dry with a towel can lead to fading.

steps.title: Heat styling tools cause your hair to fade.
steps.content: Heat styling tools cause your hair to fade. If you really love your curling or flat iron, spritz heat protectant spray all over your blue hair before you start styling. [12] X Research source The best way to protect your hair is by avoiding heat styling altogether. If you really want to curl or straighten your hair, use heat protecting products first, and set your tools to a low temperature, like 350 °F (177 °C). [13] X Research source

steps.title: Direct sunlight can fade your hair.
steps.content: Direct sunlight can fade your hair. As a precaution, apply a UV protectant hair spray or treatment all over your hair before heading outside for the day. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Chlorine and chlorinated water can lead to fading.
steps.content: Chlorine and chlorinated water can lead to fading. To keep your hair’s beautiful blue shade intact, take a break from the pool. If you’d still like to take a dip, slip on a cap before heading into the water. [15] X Research source
